newsitem.title: BURUNDI: Mines, weapons found in Burundi capital, army says.
newsitem.headline: Mines, weapons found in Burundi capital, army says.

text.p: Police found arms and ammunitions including anti-tank and anti-personnel mines in Burundi's capital Bujumbura on Wednesday and arrested four people, the army said.
Army Spokesman Lieutenant-Colonel Isaie Nibizi said the arms were found hidden in Buyenzi district in Bujumbura and thanked the public for a tip-off. He said police were investigating.

"The information at our disposal is incomplete. Burundi has many criminals and ethnic groups. But if the conclusions of our investigation implicate ex-president (Jean Baptiste) Bagaza, we will tell you," Nibizi told reporters.
Authorities said last month they had arrested eight people including five members of the Parena party, led by Bagaza, who were plotting to kill military ruler Pierre Buyoya.
Bujumbura has been rocked by a series of mine blasts since March in a campaign by opponents of Buyoya. The explosions killed 15 people and wounded 12.
Burundi's Foreign Minister Luc Rukingama however said mine blasts might continue until all the "criminals" were caught.
Meanwhile wounded soldiers at the military hospital in Bujumbura said on Wednesday fighting was continuing in the southern province of Makamba near the border with Tanzania.
They said fighting started last Thursday when a group of Hutu rebels entered from Tanzania and killed two civilians.
More than 150,000 people have been killed in massacres and fighting between the Tutsi-dominated army and rebels since the killing of Burundi's first elected Hutu president in October 1993.
Regional states, which imposed sanctions shortly after last July's coup to pressure Buyoya into peace talks with the rebels, plan a summit in the northern Tanzanian town of Arusha next Wednesday.
